Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Pyrolysis of Woody Biomass for Advanced Products
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is wide spread, impacting many market sectors. Torrefied/carbonized agricultural waste, as a platform technology, has many commercial applications ranging from water filtration and environmental remediation to advanced biocomposites. Each year agricultural waste, that has little to no nutritional value, is tilled under or burned in open-fields to dispose of waste vegetation before the next growing season. The burning of agricultural waste can add nutrients back into the nutrient depleted soil after a long growing season however this practice creates undesirable pollution. Through the use of microwave heated on-site torrefaction (a thermal process that converts the biomass into a coal-like substance having better fuel characteristics than the original biomass), the once unwanted waste can be used in value-added applications such as soil remediation, water filtration, and advanced biocomposites while alleviating the pollution created from open-field burning. Any of the unused torrefied biomass at the torrefaction site can be sold for profit with lower shipping costs than untreated biomass due to the densification that occurs during the torrefaction. If brought to commercialization this technology would have a broad impact on the agricultural, construction, automotive, and plastics markets, while alleviating pollution due to open field burning of agricultural waste and bring increased utilization of biomass that helps emerging biomass suppliers enter new markets.

This I-Corps project is looking at the commercialization of on-site or integrated torrefaction of agricultural waste using microwave energy for use in environmental remediation, soil amendment, and advanced biocomposite applications. Torrefaction is a process similar to the roasting of coffee beans and is a well-known process used to produce alternative energy. The solid by-product of torrefaction, biochar, has many uses from energy production to soil amendments. However, the transportation of biochar in large quantities has proven to have several risks associated with it including spontaneous combustion. On-site torrefaction allows for the production of biochar where it will be used, thus eliminating explosion, fire, and health hazards associated with the transport of large quantities. The implementation of on-site torrefaction for agriculture also eliminates the smoke pollution created from open-field burning, while still allowing for the utilization of biochar as soil amendments to return much needed nutrients back to fields. The current torrefaction technology is too large and cumbersome to warrant mobile torrefaction units that are easily moved from one site to another. This project looks to microwave technology to scale down the size of mobile torrefaction units making them more feasible to take from job site to job site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work was focused on establishing product market fit for various uses of torrefied biomass. Going into the I-Corps cohort the plan was to develop a business around torrefaction with the solid by-product being sold to material compounders, plastic conversion companies, seed treatment facilities, and water treatment plants. Through the first several interviews it was very clear that the time and costs associated with EPA registration made the applications of seed treatments a difficult path for a brand new business. The next round of interviews focused on the use of torrefied biomass as filler in composite materials. It became very clear that a lack of knowledge among compounders and plastic converters made it difficult to introduce a new filler into the market place. While it is possible to go out and educate new customers, it takes too much time and money for a start-up company to educate customers quick enough to make a profitable business.

Based on the customer interviews the team decided to pivot the business focus to a custom compounder. Through the next round of interviews the team worked to develop the product market fit for small niche market product development customers that utilized renewable materials with unique sustainable messages. It became clear very quickly that these smaller customers had issues getting customized materials from larger compounding companies because they hold such a small part of the material market. This is the key value proposition the team can offer to its customers.

At the start of the I-Corps cohort the idea was to develop a new business that would result in a new entity being formed. However as the business model pivoted it became clear that incorporating this business model into an existing company (c2renew inc.) was the better option. The established relationship with the University for processing, testing, and technology transfer would save the team time and money allowing for a quick transition into fulfilling customer requests for samples and orders. Since the closing of the cohort the team has applied for three SBIR/STTR grants along with some state funded grants. In addition, the PI and IM have taken over a junior/senior level undergraduate engineering course on Entrepreneurship for Engineers and Scientists where they will use the I-Corps Lean Startup methodologies in the curriculum.
